reviews.review_title: Perhaps the best entry in the "Irish Folklore Trilogy."
reviews.content: I wasn't sure what to expect when I sat down to watch the third installment in Tomm Moore's "Irish Folklore Trilogy." The Secret of Kells (2009) was a unique animation style that also carried over to Song of the Sea (2014). Wolfwalkers (2020) continues this "rough" visual style but perhaps has the strongest story of all three films. That's not to say its predecessors don't have interesting stories, it's more that Wolfwalkers builds upon the foundations established by these previous entries of this loose trilogy.As is the case with these films, Wolfwalkers follows a young girl (Robyn Goodfellowe (Honor Kneafsey)) who encounters the fantasy of the world adjacent to her own. Both The Secret of Kells and Song of the Sea andShapeshifting wolves and disappearing forests are more complex than she first realizes. Many stories based on ancient lore are meant to teach lessons to children, and this movie is no different. Granted, there are quite a few cliches in how the plot progresses, being quite predictable at times. Still, the story is engaging enough to warrant a viewing.This movie first came to my attention when I saw it tied to advertisements for Apple TV+. As this is yet another streaming service on top of the ones already well established (and with significantly more content than Apple TV+ has), I was disappointed that such a marvelous, Oscar-nominated film like Wolfwalkers was basically trapped behind a paywall. I don't know if this movie will ever be released on Blu-ray, but for right now I'd suggest dipping your toe into Apple TV+ with a free trial just to watch this one piece of content.Perhaps the best entry in the "Irish Folklore Trilogy," I give Wolfwalkers 4.5 stars out of 5.

Beautifully animated in various styles and boasting a great lyrical soundtrack, "Wolfwalkers" also touches our minds with its authentic philosophical message about deforestation and the bridging of cultural differences.

reviews.review_title: Loved the animation style and characters. Maybe a little bit predictable toward the end.
reviews.content: "WolfWalkers" is a rare gem, and I am glad that I have watched it. I enjoyed the animation that I have found stunning and truly different. Congratulations to Apple that distributed this piece of art. We need more movies like this one, please.The medieval-like soundtrack perfectly matches with the mood and the story. There are a few tracks that mix perfectly the tradition of old popular music, with modern lyrics. I went immediately to search for the tracklist and I am absolutely stunned by the work done.Every element in this movie immersed me in this fairy tale and I was totally invested on the plot. The story is not very original to be fair, but it is simple and straightforward. Everyone can watch this movie and feel entertained, it has a nice development: nothing feels out of place or dragged out. There is a nice buildup and a lot of tension. It is very dynamic, but not too violent. "WolfWalkers" is one of the best animation movies of 2020, in my opinion, and it earned completely 9 stars out of 10.

An apple original picture WolfWalkers tells the story of a young English girl named Robyn who lives with her father in a settlement in medieval Ireland. The town's expansion is halted when a pack of wolfs terrorize the settlers resulting in Robyn. Father pursuing them. One day Robyn meets a girl among the wolves named Mebh who's a Wolfwalker. A Druid essentially with her mother lives among them, and channels magic to become Wolves in their sleep. The two of them develop a friendship with one another and everything seems good. Until One night Robyn finds herself turned into a wolf and becomes a Wolfwalker herself. All while the lord protector puts the squeeze on the region to drive the wolves out permanently. A lot of the time animation usually has a message that people primarily kids can take away from it. So Wolfwalkers isn't exactly the first to go with that original concept, it still manages to take its story and deliver not only a colorful film but also show the darker side of such elements. The themes of freedom and oppression are present throughout the movie. Right off the back, introduce how Robyn's father says how they're not exactly welcome here being English In Ireland and how Robyn is scoffed at it by the locals for being who she is. Combine that with the very Strict old totalitarian laws they have to abide by themselves orchestrated by the Lord protector of this town who's a fanatic. He makes a good villain he's basically like Frollo mixed with Radcliffe from Pocahontas. It's more for those reasons I felt that the chemistry between her and Mebh is even greater. Mebh is more easy-going she's not constrained by any rules and could just do as she, pleases. I also really liked Sean Bean as the father you see his kinda character in other animation features such as how to train your Dragon or brave strong tough guy he's not a bad guy but he just worries and cares for a kid. Even though right off the back he doesn't side with the girl with his daughter you know he's not a bad guy or you got understand his actions. The art itself is remarkably impressive given a very unique style to it. It gives the movie a more of a fantasy feel as to how the backgrounds are drawn in vivid colors. It looks like a child's folktale book brought to life, with the Celtic theme, I music is really good. Some of the creative angles used for certain perspectives give off these very trippy magic picture shots almost. As well as the great use of colors and lights to symbolize more somber lighthearted tones to the more dark and serious tones with such colors as red and blue.

The best pun I could come up with for this was "Princess Potatoke".Cause if you've seen Princess Mononoke, you will definitely be thinking about it a lot while watching this. And oh god, is it Irish. It's so Irish that, being English, if I wanted to review this fairly, I had to fight back decades of colonialist instinct thanks to Boris trying his damnedest to bring it back.As you might guess from my opening statement, my biggest issue with this is that occasionally, it can feel a bit "been there, done that". I for one would be stunned if Princess Mononoke wasn't a pretty big inspiration for this, but the film also plays it maybe a little bit too safe for my liking in general. It feels like it's slightly pushing the label of "kids' film" at points, and I think it would have been cool to see it take that just a little bit further.But everything else...well, let's start with the obvious. The animation is just *chef's kiss* gorgeous, and the fact that this studio is one of the last holdouts seemingly dedicated to 2D animation in a time where even Ghibli is giving CGI some flirtatious looks is enough to make me want to sail over to Ireland right now and bring them a pot of gold. The line work, the backgrounds, the character design, the matte paintings, the style in general, the fact that it made first person wolf running scenes leagues above Bram Stoker's Dracula, everything about this film is ravishing to the eyes.The performances are great, even the 12 and 8 year olds that play the two leads...actually, scratch that, especially the 12 and 8 year olds that play the two leads. They bring so much heart and charm to these characters that it's honestly hard to imagine them any other way. Sean Bean is the best he's been probably since Game Of Thrones, and Simon McBurney (that's one hell of a fitting name) just has such a punchable voice. It's great for this role.The story, while it can be a little derivative, has really good and meaningful choices throughout it, that I can't really explain without spoiling, it's directed amazingly well, playing with different animation styles, aspect ratios, and in general there's just some well thought out shots, and oh man the soundtrack. I always thought the original version of Running With The Wolves sounded way too overproduced, and I'm glad someone apparently agreed with me, because the simpler, more folky version of it here is beautiful.And whether I would have preferred this to win over Soul? Well...I'm not sure which one I prefer at this moment, but...come on, Pixar have won enough times by now. That's all I'm saying.

reviews.content: We couldn't wait to get the latest film from Cartoon Saloon, an Irish studio which still uses (basically) hand-drawn animation, after I heard about it through the academy award nomination. WolfWalkers oddly took a very long time to be released on blu ray in the USA, and when it finally was, it was only available through a package with other films from the same studio. But in our book, Cartoon Saloon is so good--right up there with Studio Ghibli, and, yes, Disney/Pixar--that I got the package anyway, even if it meant duplicates in our collection. Despite the academy award consideration, it's not quite as good as its predecessors The Secret of Kells, Song of the Sea, or the Breadwinner. Still excellent, however, and notable for its very specific and detailed historical fiction, which seems rare in children's animation or literature. Baked into the portrayal of the Cromwellian occupation of Ireland is the fantasy plot of WolfWalkers--Irish lycanthropes who release their wolf-spirit during sleep--and the daughter of an English general who befriends them, gets bitten, and turns into one herself. The allusions to Ghibli's Princess Mononoke are plentiful, but well considered, and creatively blended with Irish folklore; in this case it's the English occupiers who are destroying and de-enchanting the forest-the Irish primeval wood-for the sake of pre-industrialization. In short: worth the hype, even if the hype should have come sooner for Cartoon Saloon.

You can change individual narrative components and storylines, but ultimately you have to follow the overall quality-tested and approved narrative blueprint if you want to make a movie for Disney/Pixar.Wolfwalkers is such a breath of fresh air coming out of Europe. It looks and feels so different than what you are conditioned to after watching Toy Story, Moana, and Frozen for the 100th time each. In a vacuum, the plot reads as a bit derivative, and perhaps it is. But the way the story is told and depicted feels so different. You would know, right off the bat, that this is made by someone other than Pixar/Disney, even if you did not know that prior. The beautiful hand-crafted animation is the first giveaway. When was the last time we saw any animated movie, by anyone, that looks as good as this? The way people talk and act is the next thing I noticed. It is hard to put into words but it is just different than what we are conditioned to. There is no "deconstruction" of kids' movie tropes here. The protagonist is a strong young woman, but she is organically strong. She is not strong in the caricatured 2021 sense of "strong young woman who recites feminist political lines and hates men" that we see even in kids' movies today. Wolfwalkers is not a front for any political themes at all. There are no "mansplaining" references here. Wolfwalkers is just a great kids movie that your kids can watch and take inspiration from.Give this movie a watch. You will not be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Not Pixar, and that's a good thing
reviews.content: Look, I'm not saying Pixar is bad. They've consistently given us the some of the best animated films over the years, and while the Oscars seems to have a fascination with them most of their wins are well deserved.That is, until Cars 2.After Cars 2, they've been reduced to making agreeable sequels of their most classic titles, much to the disappointment of those waiting for the next Ratatouille. Sure, there was Inside Out too, but that's one good movie in a sea of mediocrity. Disney Animation has somewhat picked up the mantle, but even their best films are but a minor copy of better Pixar films.Wolfwalkers is what the world of animation needed, and for this reason it is even more saddening to accept that it will most likely fade into obscurity quickly. Cartoon Saloon delivers another 2D masterpiece that is neither anime or Pixar. Unlike Song of the Sea, the plot is simple and follow a conventional storytelling method. It works for what it is, but isn't particularly compelling nor is it the driving force of this film.The strength of the film lies in its incredible visuals, and when something has such an obvious strength, the rest just has to avoid being a detriment. It knowingly pulls its punches with the plot, knowing that a more complicated plot will take attention away from from its main strength and appeal. This approach to priority is similar to other visually powerful productions such as Kubo and the Two Strings and the Wallace and Gromit series.Do not for one moment think that this is just a film with pretty backgrounds. The fine craft of this masterpiece truly shines in motion and shadow. Everything is exaggerated, fluid and incredibly detailed. The background, lighting and shadows are all effectively manipulated to control the scene and create direction, motion and focus, something only possible in the world of traditional animation (and even then so rarely done).We tend to give little recognition to those that deserve it, and instead choose the easy path with obvious choices. Big Hero 6 won the Best Animated Feature with The Tale of Princess Kaguya and Song of the Sea in competition, despite being a merely average animated film. While Wolfwalkers is currently nominated for the Best Animated Feature, it seems unlikely that it will win over Soul.Of course, an award isn't everything. Whether it gains widespread acclaim or fades into obscurity, the best we can do individually is be glad that we were able to experience this film. Do yourself a favor and watch Wolfwalkers.

reviews.review_title: Wolfwalkers - Odyssey of the Senses By Maria Elena Gutierrez
reviews.content:
In Wolfwalkers, a young English girl called Robyn Goodfellowe escapes Kilkenny, the Irish town to which she has been brought by her father, in order to explore the wonders of the surrounding forest. In doing so, she turns her back on the world of human beings and opens herself to the world of wolves.At this fundamental level, Wolfwalkers can be seen as a story of the conflict between civilization and nature. To this end, directors Tomm Moore and Ross Stewart employ two distinct visual styles. The town of Kilkenny is rendered in flat geometric shapes and dark colors. It is oppressive, solid like a block. Thematically this represents the English Puritanical religious views of 1650, and the embodiment of this is the Lord Protector. When he first shows up, the frame is almost devoid of color: his suit and headgear are black and white, with only a splash of red in the emblem on his flag, which symbolizes the violence and killing of the wolves.In contrast, the world of the forest is an enchanted paradise. It looks like a three-dimensional watercolor painting - it's fluid and loose, filled with energy and life. When we see the wolves running through the trees, they move like liquid. All of this tells us that nature is the space of creativity, the space of liberation. Indeed, Mebh openly tells Robyn: "Come and be free in the forest. Come and play."
While the design of the town draws on woodcut illustrations from the period, the forest owes a clear debt to the highly decorative manuscripts produced by Irish and British monks between 700-1,000 AD, known as "insular illumination" and perhaps best represented by the wonderful Book of Kells. This artistic tradition used sophisticated interlacing and zoomorphic decoration to represent the complexity of nature, its deep interconnectedness, and its organic wholeness. In a luscious visual vegetation, images grow one into the other while animals lurk enigmatically in the background. Not surprisingly, this form of art is an ideal match for a story where nature plays a central role. Sometimes, the visual complexity and the dynamism of images in Wolfwalkers is so exuberant that we have the impression of entering a new visual world resembling that of the Viennese Secession, best exemplified by the work of Gustav Klimt.Having passed from the hard, geometric world of the town into the fluid space of the forest, Robyn meets Mebh, a girl about her age who is the embodiment of the natural world. This contrast between town and countryside is echoed in the design of these two protagonists. Look at Mebh, and you will see that the shape of her hair resembles a leaf; her face is round like a heart. But Robyn, who desperately wants to be a hunter, has a face shaped like an arrow; in certain sequences her cape takes the shape of an arrow, too.The world of nature has yet another aspect, because it is also a space of magic and ritual. We first see evidence of this in the inscriptions on the walls of the cave where Mebh resides with her mother and the wolves. These markings immediately transport us back to a time when human beings first felt the need to represent sacred beings through drawing. In this way the cave represents our relationship to the divine world and reminds us that, in order to forge the future, we must first explore the past.Venturing deeper into the cave, we discover Mebh's mother represented in a way that evokes ideas of a Mother Earth Goddess. This returns us to the sacred moment when humans and animals lived in symbiosis, and again we see this story recounted on the walls of the cave. As we absorb the ancient narrative, we realise we are in the presence of the divine.Even the shape of the cave is suggestive and full of meaning, resembling as it does female anatomy. In this and many other ways, the movie is a celebration of woman.For example, Robyn is an archetype of the woman standing against the oppressive authority of men, just like Antigone, stood against her uncle Creon in order to honor paganism and the oral laws of the gods. There are clear echoes of Antigone's story in Wolfwalkers, where the townspeople are told repeatedly that terrible things will to happen if they cut down the trees. At one point, the woodcutter explains to Robyn's father that Saint Patrick made a pact with the pagan god. As for the Wolfwalkers themselves- they are the magical gods, the divinities who have existed in the forest since primordial times, since before history began.Wolfwalkers is also a celebration of the senses. When Robyn passes from the hard, geometric world of the town into the fluid space of the forest - and in particular when she transforms into a wolf - Mebh tells her not to rely on her eyes. Instead, Robyn must learn to use her other senses - her sense of smell, or the feel of the earth beneath her paws. Mebh is there to guide her - and also us, the audience - into this sensory world.In addition, beyond even the power of the senses, Mebh possesses the healing power of magic. Yet she cannot cure her mother alone. In order to do that she needs help. She needs the pack, the community, the collective. The power of the family. Even this heroine, this girl with superhero powers, cannot succeed alone. The ultimate message of Wolfwalkers, therefore, stands in defiance of individualism. If we as human beings are going to heal nature, we need each other.Dr. Maria Elena Gutierrez is the CEO and executive director of VIEW Conference, Italy's premiere annual digital media conference. VIEW Conference is committed to bringing a diversity of voices to the forefront in animation, visual effects and games.

Wolfwalkers is a story about a British hunter family investigating the Irish lands for wolves, but more importantly, its about finding happiness while being in a cage. The way it chronicles its protagonist Robyn trying to handle her own independence from her overprotective father is amazing, and it shows respect to both sides instead of painting things on the side of one person. Wolfwalkers, and Cartoon Saloon films in general, capture some sort of spirit that you look for in Disney, but it isn't quite there. Every little step and scene means something, and the stakes climb higher and higher. Combine all this with amazing animation and angelic music. My favorite character was Mebh due to the rawness of her emotion and how she never stopped fighting for Moll, even in a town full of people wanting to execute them both. The scene where she screamed for her mother was tearjerking.Now, spoiler time. Remember what I said earlier about Bill, Robyn's father? I think what was important about the film showing his side with respect was that, in a lot if ways, Bill was becoming Cromwell, even though his intentions were to keep Robyn safe. If it wasn't for him realizing his ways earlier, he would have become no different from the man who wanted to kill his daughter for who she was. Bill thought he was an ally of Cromwell, but at the end of the day he was someone who Cromwell saw as just as disposable as the rest of the wolves. What stopped him from going down that path was doing what broke him down the most, and letting Robyn go. He wanted her to be happy, and the only way for that was to let her be herself, and she could only be herself if she was free. The movie repeatedly brought up the theme of freedom contrasted with safety, and in the end, they all earned both together. An underrated film, it deserves more recognition and revive a new genre of children's movies and 2D animation.

reviews.review_title: A very special animation about revolution!
reviews.content: This is one of the best animated stories I have ever seen in my life. Better than Song Of The Sea and its predecessor.The animation is gorgeous and rich; especially the striking red colors used to convey drama. Yet it remains inventive and flexible; an artistic treat to watch. There is minimalism where it is needed and flare where it is required. The music and voice acting falls in step with the art; creating something special.The main characters express an endearing humanity; that gives the show something most vapid cash cows cannot achieve; sympathy with the characters.While the plot and story are not overly complicated, this is because the movie is mainly meant for children. The story still manages to impress even adults with its general message of; courage, revolutionary action, selflessness, and love.Spoiler. The story centres around a young girl named Robin and her father; a hunter called Goodfellow. The two are newly arrived outsiders who live in a constricting town ruled by a Lord Protector; who is basically a petty dictator. Under English rule, the Irish people are forced to work for their dictator and fell a nearby forest; even Children are forced into labor by an unrelenting, mechanical government.Goodfellow is charged with hunting down the wolves in the neighbouring woods. Parts of the story are a metaphor for any minority group being oppressed; which is what Mave and here mother (who are wolfwalkers-people capable of turning into wolves when they sleep) are. Mave and her mother live in the woods which are being invaded and threatened by the town. Mave wants to leave but cannot because her mother is asleep and her mother's wolf counterpart has not returned. Mave and Robin become friends after Mave heals her hawk Merlin.The plot takes a fun twist when Robin is accidentally bitten by Mave and becomes a wolfwalker herself. Which symbolises becoming one of the minority/oppressed groups. Robin is suddenly forced to deal with the hate,violence and superstition that is felt towards wolves. An irony, because earlier in the movie she herself oppressed wolves; seeing them only as vicious beasts to be hunted down.Robin promises to help Mave find her mother, but is forced by her society and its leader into conformity and obedience. Mave's mother who has actually been captured by the Lord Protector is placed in a physical and metaphorical cage. Upon her execution, she is freed by Robin who decides to break free of her own cage; freeing herself of her towns conformity and rigid rule.Riding the giant wolf who is actually Maves mother; the two make a dramatic escape from the town. Maves mother is reunited with her daughter; but is shot by Robins father; Goodfellow. Robin turns into a wolf; choosing to go with Mave and the wolves into the forest to help Maves injured mother.An epic battle takes place in which Goodfellow throws off his own chains of conformity; choosing to turn into a wolf to save his daughter. The Lord Protector is defeated; Goodfellow redeems himself and all four survive and become a single family-like a wolf pack.In conclusion; this animated movie is one of a kind, and is well worth the watch. The story, metaphors and messages are much deeper than most neigh sayers, and haters think.Don't miss this one!

The characters are each beautifully designed. And through the expressive animation and talented voice acting of these young girls who played the protagonists, very little character development is needed for the audience to be quickly enveloped in their journey.The story, although initially about humans take over of nature, friendship and how a man can become blinded by ambition based on fear, the story hold metaphors for a deeper meaning about English occupationism in Ireland. The forest does not welcome and acts hostile towards the town, and the town occupy's and cuts down the forest. The animated film Wolf Walkers is filled with adventure, fantasy, friendship and love. The film takes place in the 17th century in Ireland, in a small village known as Kilkenny. There is a phenomenon or belief that "wolf walkers" are amongst them. In this village lives a young, fiery-haired girl named Robyn, along with her wolf hunting father. Within the forest surrounding the village, lives a young girl named Mebh, who is otherwise known as a "wolf walker". The village of Kilkenny is ruled by a man known as Lord Protector, who despises the wolves and wants to terminate them. During this time of the film, the men were known to work and be "strong", while the women were known to clean and be "neat". The main character Robyn did not like that way of life, instead she wanted to follow her father's footsteps in becoming a wolf hunter.
	In the beginning of the film, Robyn is seeking out her passion for wolf hunting, while her father is trying to keep her from it for her safety. Robyn disregards her father's wishes and continues to try to hunt for wolves on her own. On Robyn's journey to find some wolves she stumbles upon a magical entryway into the wolf's den. She then encounters a young girl named Mebh, who is a wolf walker. At first Robyn was petrified and still tried to defend herself against the wolves and even Mebh. Mebh then showed and explained to Robyn that Mebh's mother is stuck asleep and out as a wolf still. Robyn and Mebh's friendship blossomed from that point and Robyn's new duty was to help Mebh find her mother. In the village of Kilkenny the townspeople believed the wolves were of demonic nature, just as witches. The Lord Protector made sure to do everything in his power to destroy the last pack of wolves amongst his village, from sending out hunters to even suggesting to burn all of the forest down. 
	One aspect of this film that should be recognized and spoken about is the soundtrack and editing. The soundtrack within this film is what gave the auidence suspension and the feeling of being "at the edge of your seat". From Robyn and Mebh riding wolves through the forest to Robyn trying to find Mebh's mother. The editing in Wolf Walkers is so astonishing, the colors and scenery given were impeccable. The beautiful forest full of magical yellow, shimmery lights, to the sketched movements of the wolves. Even the costume design of the characters suited each of them so well. The visualization of this film showing each pencil sketch was truly unique that not a lot of films show that.
 The way the destruction of culture, nature and independence under colonialism in the 1600s was shown through the village of Kilkenny was super informational. It showed aspects of the story most of audiences may have not seen or even paid attention to. From Robyn working as a castle maid for Lord Protector, to Robyn's father being a hunter and then even a warrior. These times were traumatic and added more compassion to Robyn's journey and her feelings, or even a better understanding of why Robyn said or did certain things.  
	I believed this film was truly a masterpiece, the scenery, the plot, the characters, and even that little bird Robyn loved so much. Seeing a film in a time where morals were so different than they are today gave me a lot of respect for Robyn and her journey. This film was full of adventure and suspense, you never knew what was going to happen next. I enjoyed the art behind the film, the sketches of movement still shown, I believe really emphasized the hard work put into each scene. To any viewers who have not seen this film I would highly recommend it due to the beautiful simplicity and power of friendship and love. The story is more than just a 17th century colonized village ran by a "lord", Wolf Walkers is a once in a lifetime experience of a film and if I could watch it for the first time all over again I would.

Wolfwalkers as a Journey of Multiple Lenses
"Wolfwalkers" as an animated film has many easter eggs laid out within its dialogue. Brief recurring themes of historical and religious events. These events are presented in a way intended not to take away from the entertainment value and artistic representation of the folklore. The setting of Ireland in 1650 following the Irish Rebellion of 1641, with insights into the religious and social expectations of Protestant ideas. All while existing in the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy. Historical details are dispersed through the lenses of ecology, social economics, feminism, and folklore.
The narrative of segregated unsupervised girls, finding their way in a new world. All while making their voices heard is exhibited throughout. Even as the opinions of the girls are dismissed.  The movie has two main characters that suggest feminist thought.  Robyn is an inexperienced hunter of wolves who seeks adventure. Her mother is assumed deceased, and her father is away during the days while hunting wolves. Her father has been recruited by the Lord to remove the wolves from the surrounding woods. Mebh is the alpha of the pack of wolves. She is thrust into this role after her mother has been perceived to have abandoned her. The town is ruled by the authoritarian Lord Protector, who is presented as a figurehead for the church and a relentless leader. The townspeople are fearful of Lord Protector and are ordered to cut down the surrounding forest.  The same forest that Robyn wants to explore and Mebh lives as a wolfwalker. A wolfwalker is the town's folklore of humans who transform into wolves at night.
The plot unfolds as Robyn sneaks out of the castle gates exhibiting her independence. During her strike of rebellion against her father, is consequently bitten by a wolf. The wolf, Mebh, tries to heal Robyn with a Reki touch. The injury was unintentional and even though Mebh is the alpha wolf, she is playful and cub-like. Robyn and Mebh bicker like siblings while both exhibiting traits of powerful female expression. Robyn believes her skillset is at the level of her father, even though she is inexperienced in the woods and as a hunter.   Robyn strives for adventure and mostly is ignored when she speaks. Mebh is a wild girl who does as she pleases without concern for repercussions.  All while enjoying her life, eating as she pleases, and howling at the moon. The traits of having an opinion and seeking adventure in a male-dominated sport are contradictory to the traditional ways some women are raised. With the addition of having no concern while being authentic and not taking social protocol in decision-making. Both show feminist ideas. 
After being bitten, Robyn is human while awake and a wild wolf while sleeping. Robyn tries to express this to her father and confirm that the folklore is indeed true, but he is fearful of the consequences from the townsfolk, and most importantly Lord Protector. He largely ignores Robyn and speaks of wanting to protect her. He sends her to work with a scullery and assigns her housework. Robyn ignores most of the assignments and only complies when she believes it will benefit her. This technique can be argued as an example of women using what power they have for their benefit, to be heard, and respected. 
The spread of the legend was first told to be authentic by a townsperson with first-hand experience with wolfwalkers. He was quickly considered insane and falsely accused of spreading false rumors which landed him in the pillory.  In the town square, he is prominently displayed to reinforce the power of the state and align the Lord protectors' structure of obedience. With this fear in mind, Robyn's father either ignores her or silences her, even when the reality is directly in front of him as a tangible wolf.
The forests are to be ignited and burnt down as a result of wolves being found in the village. Lord Protector ignores the economic logic and reasoning of the townspeople. The townspeople not only are afraid of injury from the wolves. The ethics of approaching and occupying the forest is whispered among the masses. The ideology of environmental impact and deforestation is questioned by townspeople.  
 The townspeople continue to represent the power of folklore throughout the movie by communicating through whispers and oral traditions. Secretly doubting the leadership of Lord Protector. Their concerns are based on the consequences of such action being discovered. The power dynamics of workers' rights and the freedom of religion are questioned. Most of the oral tradition takes place during times of manual labor, by unskilled workers,
The plot allows the viewer to dive as far as they wish into the lens of feminist thought, religious power, and additional social viewpoints. Without taking away from the magic of a children's movie. It is enjoyable to watch and explores the humanities and social issues. This allows viewers of all ages to see a glimpse of still frames of justice. 
While watching for entertainment as events unfold you are mesmerized. The conscious choice of the animators to use techniques that allow the images to be observed as brush strokes and pencil drawings. Is placed throughout the movie in a way that is not overwhelming and you forget is present.  As if not only the viewer is in a magical place, but also a storybook. The color choices and animation are beautiful and a joy to watch.  This is layered with the soundtrack of songs that both ring a familiarity of Irish with a splash of what could be mistaken for indigenous. Aurora Aksne's voice is a compliment to the power of Robyn and Mebh. and her song ‘Running with the wolves' stands on its own pedestal of power. I highly recommend her albums and am delighted to have discovered her while watching this film. 
I recommend this film be used in all the contexts discussed above. Though I suggest focusing on questions like when do we allow ourselves to believe in magic and when to be logical? It's about time that Studio Ghibli had competition in the world of animation, and Cartoon Saloon, the studio behind "Wolfwalkers", is certainly stepping up to the slide. Absolutely beautiful 2D animation drawn heavily from ancient Celtic art, coupled with a fantastical storyline that brings to life both our childhood fantasies and deeply primal fears, creates a film that has certainly earned an eternal place in my heart. The storyline here is fantasy, but it is also remarkably, poignantly real. "Wolfwalkers" starkly highlights the forces that threaten to tear apart our world today. The townspeople live in fear of the magickal, natural power of the wolves, and the wolves live in fear of the orthodox, mechanical industry of the town. The dangers of fear-driven hierarchy are sharply contrasted against the deep seated need for open harmonious community, love, and understanding. This dualism, though well known, is not shallow in this film. The audience has the pleasure of exploring both sides of the story, and in the end, it is hard not to have compassion for everyone involved.
    Twin forces, and the larger ties that bind them, play throughout all of the scenes. This tension particularly manifests in the relationship between Mebh and Robyn. Their connection is seemingly timeless, embodying the power of mature, confident emotion contrasted with childlike devotion and idealism. Stay or go, family or friends, paganism or Christianity, the town or the wolves: their relationship stands as a connecting point between these opposing sides. Robyn's fear of Mebh as a wolfwalker is overcome once understanding and love are allowed to enter the picture. Cartoon Saloon has taken the unending truth of love over fear and presented it in a beautiful, sincere, heartwarming way.
    Storyline and heartstrings aside, this film is also visually outstanding. It truly would be a shame to discuss only the plot. I am personally a lifelong fan of Cartoon Saloons first film, "The Secret of Kells," and "Wolfwalkers" met and exceeded all of my expectations for the artistic prowess and commitment of this studio. Their phenomenal attention to the details of the forest, the swirling and emotive song-long montage of Mebh and Robyn during her first night as a wolf, the brilliantly telling character design and obvious effort put into every aspect of the visual process make this a movie that deserves to stand out among modern animated works. Cartoon Saloon has taken archetypal visual tropes and reimagined them in spellbindingly beautiful ways. It is truly a wonderful achievement, and resulted in a film that is profoundly irresistible. Emotionally and visually, "Wolfwalkers" is a display of the storytelling power of modern film. We can only hope that other studios will follow suit along this remarkable and mesmerizing path.

Move over, Disney! There's another animation studio gifting us animated films. If you are looking to be truly captivated by a beautiful world of animation, splendor and lore, then forget streaming Disney+. Consider 2020's Wolfwalkers as your film of choice. Released by Irish animation studio, Cartoon Saloon (notable for having its first four feature films nominated for Best Animated Feature at the Academy Awards), Wolfwalkers is the final installment of a trilogy of films exploring Irish folklore stories. No actors well-known in American cinema, save for Mr. Sean Bean (The Lord of the Rings: Fellowship of the Ring, National Treasure, The Island), lend their voices to the film. Rightly so, as American A-listers are sometimes distracting in their animated voice roles (Seth Rogen in DreamWorks' Kung Fu Panda trilogy, for example). While the film is a tad longer than necessary for its story, you can't help but be transfixed by the textural prowess of the animation it offers.

We enter into the world of Wolfwalkers by meeting a young girl named Robin, voiced by Honor Kneafsey, and her father, a hunter named Goodfellowe (Sean Bean), who have just moved to a newly colonized Ireland village in the 1600s. Robin wants to help her dad hunt as she did in England, but the expectation for her is to be a maid. She immediately defies his instruction to stay within the village and ventures into the surrounding forest and encounters a wolf. Later, she meets another young girl named Mebh (pronounced "MAYb"). Despite realizing Mebh is the wolf she encountered earlier, the two eventually befriend one another. As the film unfolds, we explore themes of friendship, freedom, courage, and love. All of what we see is taken to grander heights by the stellar voice work throughout the film, notably Kneafsey, Bean and Eva Whittaker as Mebh.

This movie may, at first, remind the audience of films that came before it, such as Quest for Camelot, Brave and How to Train Your Dragon, just due to setting, score and tone, but later in the film, you realize the lead in each of these films is struggling under the weight of the same problem: the desire to break away from the oppression of social norms, and the insatiable desire to be free. (Free to be a knight who saves Camelot, free to choose whether or not to be married, free to befriend a dragon, or in this case, free to explore the forest and be something more than a scullery maid). However, it manages to carve out its own story amidst a visual animation style that will make you want to return for multiple viewings.

Visually, it is a bonafide triumph. Wolfwalkers makes you feel as though you are watching a classic storybook come to life. After a mere ten minutes into the film, you will be captivated, perhaps even delighted, by its texture and classic animation style. Though some (few, really) of the background characters were a bit reminiscent of new-ish Cartoon Network-style animation fodder like Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends, the true magic and wonder is found in the picturesque landscape of the forest, the extra effort displayed in the animation of our heroine, and the Wolfwalkers themselves. The wolves move like the wind, as if they were a physical representation of the jet streams we learned about as grade schoolers in science class. The color and texture of the forest will make you wish you could enter in to the Wolfwalkers' forest and have an adventure of your own.

While the film does its best visual storytelling in the scenes where we find Robin alone, it also does a fantastic job of depicting how some of the greatest friendships are forged by the fires of dissimilarity. There's an eternal message there, in how we never know when or how those we don't understand, or maybe don't even initially like, will one day become our closest friends. Outside of the forest, we spend entirely too much time with the villain of the film, named Lord Protector, and every moment spent forced to watch him spew his inane ramblings makes you all the more grateful for the moments we are able to escape back to the forest.

It's true the film is a little longer than it needed to be, as it does follow a bit of a formula that makes third act occurrences predictable far before they get around to making them happen. However, it is an absolute masterclass in animation, and completely captivating as a result. So, perhaps you won't mind spending an extra 30 minutes in the world of the Wolfwalkers. I know I didn't.

Wolfwalkers – Odyssey of the Senses
    By Maria Elena Gutierrez ﻿

In Wolfwalkers, a young English girl called Robyn Goodfellowe escapes Kilkenny, the Irish town to which she has been brought by her father, in order to explore the wonders of the surrounding forest. In doing so, she turns her back on the world of human beings and opens herself to the world of wolves.
At this fundamental level, Wolfwalkers can be seen as a story of the conflict between civilization and nature. To this end, directors Tomm Moore and Ross Stewart employ two distinct visual styles. The town of Kilkenny is rendered in flat geometric shapes and dark colors. It is oppressive, solid like a block. Thematically this represents the English Puritanical religious views of 1650, and the embodiment of this is the Lord Protector. When he first shows up, the frame is almost devoid of color: his suit and headgear are black and white, with only a splash of red in the emblem on his flag, which symbolizes the violence and killing of the wolves.

In contrast, the world of the forest is an enchanted paradise. It looks like a three-dimensional watercolor painting – it's fluid and loose, filled with energy and life. When we see the wolves running through the trees, they move like liquid. All of this tells us that nature is the space of creativity, the space of liberation. Indeed, Mebh openly tells Robyn: "Come and be free in the forest. Come and play."

While the design of the town draws on woodcut illustrations from the period, the forest owes a clear debt to the highly decorative manuscripts produced by Irish and British monks between 700-1,000 AD, known as "insular illumination" and perhaps best represented by the wonderful Book of Kells. This artistic tradition used sophisticated interlacing and zoomorphic decoration to represent the complexity of nature, its deep interconnectedness, and its organic wholeness. In a luscious visual vegetation, images grow one into the other while animals lurk enigmatically in the background. Not surprisingly, this form of art is an ideal match for a story where nature plays a central role. Sometimes, the visual complexity and the dynamism of images in Wolfwalkers is so exuberant that we have the impression of entering a new visual world resembling that of the Viennese Secession, best exemplified by the work of Gustav Klimt.

Having passed from the hard, geometric world of the town into the fluid space of the forest, Robyn meets Mebh, a girl about her age who is the embodiment of the natural world. This contrast between town and countryside is echoed in the design of these two protagonists. Look at Mebh, and you will see that the shape of her hair resembles a leaf; her face is round like a heart. But Robyn, who desperately wants to be a hunter, has a face shaped like an arrow; in certain sequences her cape takes the shape of an arrow, too.

The world of nature has yet another aspect, because it is also a space of magic and ritual. We first see evidence of this in the inscriptions on the walls of the cave where Mebh resides with her mother and the wolves. These markings immediately transport us back to a time when human beings first felt the need to represent sacred beings through drawing. In this way the cave represents our relationship to the divine world and reminds us that, in order to forge the future, we must first explore the past.

Venturing deeper into the cave, we discover Mebh's mother represented in a way that evokes ideas of a Mother Earth Goddess. This returns us to the sacred moment when humans and animals lived in symbiosis, and again we see this story recounted on the walls of the cave. As we absorb the ancient narrative, we realise we are in the presence of the divine.

Even the shape of the cave is suggestive and full of meaning, resembling as it does female anatomy. In this and many other ways, the movie is a celebration of woman. 

For example, Robyn is an archetype of the woman standing against the oppressive authority of men, just like Antigone, stood against her uncle Creon in order to honor paganism and the oral laws of the gods. There are clear echoes of Antigone's story in Wolfwalkers, where the townspeople are told repeatedly that terrible things will to happen if they cut down the trees. At one point, the woodcutter explains to Robyn's father that Saint Patrick made a pact with the pagan god. As for the Wolfwalkers themselves– they are the magical gods, the divinities who have existed in the forest since primordial times, since before history began. 

Wolfwalkers is also a celebration of the senses. When Robyn passes from the hard, geometric world of the town into the fluid space of the forest – and in particular when she transforms into a wolf – Mebh tells her not to rely on her eyes. Instead, Robyn must learn to use her other senses – her sense of smell, or the feel of the earth beneath her paws. Mebh is there to guide her – and also us, the audience – into this sensory world.

In addition, beyond even the power of the senses, Mebh possesses the healing power of magic. Yet she cannot cure her mother alone. In order to do that she needs help. She needs the pack, the community, the collective. The power of the family. Even this heroine, this girl with superhero powers, cannot succeed alone. The ultimate message of Wolfwalkers, therefore, stands in defiance of individualism. If we as human beings are going to heal nature, we need each other.

Cartoon Saloon, the small Irish animation studio that could, has been quietly crafting an astonishingly reliable reputation for beautiful and poignant pieces since 2009 when they got their first Oscar nomination with The Secret of Kells; though I must admit it wasn't until 2017's excellent The Breadwinner, by then their third consecutive Oscar-nomiated feature, that I finally saw one of their films. Now going for their fourth, and very likely to realise that impressive achievement, Kells' co-director Tomm Moore returns (this time with Ross Stewart) with a beautifully rendered animated feature set in 17th century Ireland under English rule, in the small town of Kilkenny where a young girl called Robyn live with her wolf-hunter single father. Her encounter with young Mebh, a wolfwalker who lives amongst the wolves and turns into one when she sleeps, kick-starts a mythological story that reflects and explores a plethora of issues including Irish history, religion, environmental preservation and societal fear of anything that doesn't conform to the mass majority. Visually, it continues in the same unique style that the studio has established with its past work, applying a more traditional approach with a rustic natural spirituality to it and the result is classy, joyful and timeless. Whilst I must confess I have a soft spot for the more realistic and uncompromising portrayal in The Breadwinner, Wolfwalkers has a more child-like fairytale quality that skewers a little younger (so it's a real winner for any kids in the audience) and feels a little too neat and child-friendly in the end, but it is the subtle and sophisticated manner in which it handles these mature issues, making them accessible to audience for all ages, that I find most welcoming and remarkable. That and the film's sumptuous aesthetics, of course.

Joy in the animation.  Set in Ireland in the 1600s, this is about an English hunter (Sean Bean) and his daughter (Honor Kneafsey).  He is here to assist with a wolf problem in the surrounding forest, but the daughter is about to learn that there is truth behind the myth: wolfwalkers are living amongst the canines.  When they are awake, they are human.  When they sleep, they transform and lead the pack.  Now I have to give credit where credit is due: Apple TV+ has been putting out some decent content during the pandemic.  I'm still working off of a year free trial, but a $5 monthly price tag isn't that steep, and it would be worth that for Ted Lasso alone.  I could see Wolfwalkers going either way.  I only have the studio's previous works to go off of, and while I thought that The Breadwinner was terrific, The Secret of Kells left me cold.  For me, Wolfwalkers falls somewhere in the middle, which ends up being a decent compliment.  If there is one area that you can't take anything away from Wolfwalkers, it would have to be the animation.  This is a gorgeous film to look at, and it is all 2D and hand-drawn.  Cartoon Saloon is a studio that has a unique style, and you can always tell when you are watching one of their films.  If nothing else, you can always rely on this movie to wow you with the visuals, and I do have to award big-time points there.  I think the pacing here works as well, and it never slows down to a point where you get bored with it.  However, I did have a problem with character interaction.  You understand where everybody is coming from, and that part is well-handled, but it is vexing because every single problem in this film stems from characters not listening to one another.  The dad wants to protect the daughter, but the daughter deliberately disobeys and throws caution to the wind.  The daughter has the solution to everyone's problem, but she gets brushed off and told to sit down.  It is problematic writing, and it holds this film back from leaping over the hurdle to that next level.  Wolfwalkers is a well-made movie.  I appreciate the craft here, and I know that this took a lot of time and energy to make.  I was invested in the story because there are stakes, and another positive I have is that actions here have consequences.  I could tell that two of the characters were going to safe, but I was never sure what everyone else's fate would be.  I think this is worth a watch, especially if you are getting Apple TV+ on a free subscription like me.

This is the latest animated film by the same director who created The Secret of Kells and Song of the Sea. Robyn and her father Bill have stationed in Ireland in 1650 at an outpost overseen by a cruel ruler. Robyn dreams of hunting wolves, like her father. One day, Robyn meets Mebh, who turns out to be a wolf walker, a creature who by day is in human form but at night can leave the sleeping body and roam the world as a wolf. This is a really beautiful film. The story is based on Celtic legend but feels very contemporary in the various themes it tackles, such as the ongoing dichotomy of human – versus – nature and the power of friendship and family. From an animation standpoint, it is simply gorgeous to watch – all of the rich colors, every scene looks like a rich watercolor, and the color changes capture the "locked in, grays and browns" feel in the city and the richer and more vibrant colors of nature. The music is beautiful with its Celtic melodies. While Song of the Sea is my all-time favorite, Wolfwalkers is quite stunning and powerful and is nearly equal in its execution of animation and narrative. This film gets a big thumbs-up from me. If you loved Secret of Kells and Song of the Sea, you will definitely like this one as well.

IN A NUTSHELL:
If you love all-things-Irish, Renaissance festivals, as well as Studio Ghibli, this Apple Original film looks and feels like a lovely combination of all of those things. Add the voice of Sean Bean. Yes, please! This magical animation is from the Academy Award-nominated makers of The Secret of Kells AND Song of the Sea and based on Irish folklore. It was directed by Tomm Moore and Ross Stewart, becoming the first animated feature to be nominated for "Best International Feature" at the Gotham Awards. The film is dedicated to Mark Stewart, who passed away this year. Cartoon Saloon continues to pump out beautiful animation films that are pretty close to visual masterpieces.

TIPS FOR PARENTS:
This is a perfect family-friendly film that all ages can enjoy.

The creators of the film explained that colonialism was the real villain in the story in that it separated protagonists from nature.

THINGS I LIKED:
The concept art is absolutely beautiful and mesmerizing. It's refreshing to see two-dimensional and under-appreciated hand-drawn animation. The colors and geometric shapes are extremely enchanting, making each frame a piece of art to be studied. One of my sons is a 3D animation artist at Blizzard and he has taught me to really appreciate the mastery of hand-drawn animation.
You really get a sense of Ireland in the 1600s
You can almost feel how damp the green forest is in animation.
Visually, the movie also illustrates the cage women of that day might have felt they were in. There are lots of angles and big black lines that represent society's rules that trapped Robyn, the young heroin in the story.
Honor Kneafsey voices the enthusiastic Robyn Goodfellowe and does a fantastic job.

Eva Whittaker lends her spunky voice to Mdbh Og MacTire.
The humor is both visual and spoken.
The British and Irish accents of the characters are super cute.

The story features the stark contrast between the magic of nature and that of the Lord Protector's rigid religious fervor. The film's creators explained that the type of Puritan religion that Lord Cromwell brought to Christianity emphasized man over nature, instead of a balance between the two: domination vs. submission. Whenever the story spotlights what's happening in the forest, the colors are light and green; to show the duality of thinking at the time, the city scenes feature grey tones in the color palette.
Clever framing devices.
The film knows when to be silent to let the audience bask in the beauty.
I loved the scene that shows Mebh Og practically melting on Robyn's lap while she gets her hair brushed by her new human friend. So sweet.

THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
The father shows warmth to his daughter but he never listens to her.
I hate it when religious people in movies are shown as truly terrible people.
